sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Infection of bone: 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of bone: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of bone: (life-threatening) 3 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; maximum 6 g/day; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: (mild to moderate) 2 g IV every 24 hours for 5 to 10 days, or 1 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days
  • Infectious disease of abdomen: 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disease of abdomen: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disease of abdomen: (life-threatening) 3 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; maximum 6 g/day; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disorder of joint: 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disorder of joint: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disorder of joint: (life-threatening) 3 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; maximum 6 g/day; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: (life-threatening) 3 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; maximum 6 g/day; depending on type and severity of infection
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: 2 g IV every 12 hours plus doxycycline 100 mg ORALLY or IV every 12 hours; continue for at least 24 hours after clinical improvement with oral doxycycline continued for a total of 14 days (guideline dosing)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: (severe) 2 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; depending on type and severity of infection (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: (life-threatening) 3 g IV every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days; maximum 6 g/day; depending on type and severity of infection (manufacturer dosing)
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis: 1 to 2 g IV 30 to 60 minutes prior to surgery
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis: (cesarean section) 1 to 2 g IV as soon as umbilical cord is clamped
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: 500 mg IV/IM every 12 hours for 5-10 days or 1 to 2 g IV/IM every 12 to 24 hours for 5 to 10 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: not FDA-approved for use in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: CrCl greater than 30 mL/min, usual dose and interval; CrCl 10 to 30 mL/min, usual dose every 24 hours (or one-half the usual dose every 12 hours); CrCl less than 10 mL/min, usual dose every 48 hours (or one-quarter the usual dose every 12 hours)
  • hemodialysis: one-quarter the usual dose every 24 hours on days between dialysis and one-half the usual dose on the day of dialysis

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Infection of bone
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Infectious disease of abdomen
  • Infectious disorder of joint
  • Lower respiratory tract infection
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to cephalosporins
  • history of cephalosporin-associated hemolytic anemia

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to penicillins
  • patients with history of gastrointestinal disease, especially colitis

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Cefotetan: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (0.6% to 1.25%), Nausea (0.14% to 1.25%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hematologic:Hemolytic anemia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Seizure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Cefotetan disodium is a semisynthetic, beta-lactamase resistant, cephalosporin antibiotic that exerts its effect by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis. Its high degree of stability in the presence of beta-lactamases is attributed to its methoxy group in the 7-alpha position. It is active against a wide range of aerobic and anaerobic gram-positive and gram-negative organisms.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 3 h to 4.6 h
  • Moderate renal impairment: 10 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intramuscular
    • reconstitute with Sterile Water for Injection, Bacteriostatic Water for Injection, NS, or 0.5% or 1% lidocaine HCl
    • add 2 mL diluent to 1 g vial for a concentration of 400 mg/mL; add 3 mL diluent to 2 g vial for a concentration of 500 mg/mL
  • Intravenous
    • reconstitute with Sterile Water for Injection
    • reconstitute 1 g vial with 10 mL for a concentration of 95 mg/mL
    • reconstitute 2 g vial with 10 to 20 mL for concentrations of 182 to 95 mg/mL
    • (bolus) may be injected directly over 3 to 5 minutes, or may be given through the tubing of an existing IV
    • (infusion) dilute further with 50 to 100 mL of D5W, NS, or other compatible diluent

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Generic
  • Injection Powder for Solution: 1 GM, 2 GM
  • Intravenous Powder for Solution: 10 GM

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion of large doses of cephalosporins may result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Seizures have developed after parenteral overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may commonly occur with therapy; oral exposures are less likely to cause severe allergic reactions than parenteral exposures. Seizures have also been reported following therapeutic administration. Prolonged prothrombin times, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathies associated with a qualitative platelet defect and aggregation abnormalities have been reported following IV cephalosporin therapy. Pseudocholelithiasis may follow intravenous administration of ceftriaxone. Several cases of fatal hemolytic reactions following intravenous ceftriaxone therapy have been reported in children with serious hematologic abnormalities.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
  • Decontamination: Generally not indicated in patients with no underlying health problems. Activated charcoal may be necessary for patients with underlying renal insufficiency.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor renal function, electrolytes, CBC including platelets.
  • Anaphylaxis: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULTS: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILDREN: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Blood coagulation disorder: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma
  • Intrathecal injection: Treat seizures with anticonvulsants (benzodiazepines, propofol, phenobarbital); endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers). For large overdoses, consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes 80 to 150 mL/hr). Dexamethasone 4 mg intravenously every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
TOXICITY: Serious toxicity is unlikely following large oral doses of cephalosporins. Crystalluria and hematuria has been described in a 3-year-old boy who ingested 104 mg/kg of cephalexin. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. CEPHALEXIN: CHILDREN: 25 to 100 milligrams/kilogram/24 hours orally, up to a maximum of 4 grams/day, divided every 6 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause diarrhea, nausea, thrombocytosis, or hemolytic anemia.
  • Patient should not drink alcohol while taking this drug.
